oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Star poems
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hanmer, Karen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Mythological constellation forms from Uranographicarum by Johannes Hevelius, 1674 portrait of Ptolemy from University of Cambridge Starry Messenger website, other star gazer images from A tutor to astronomy and geography by Joseph Moxon, 674, and Seaman's secrets by John Davis, 1657" -- Case p. [3].

"Star poems presents quotes that document response to the night sky across the ages by philosophers, artists, and poets from Plato and Byron to contemporary writers, scientists and astronauts. This text is paired with 17th century ological images of constellation forms and images of early star gazers on a background of a NASA photograph of the Milky Way. The book can be held in the hand and read page by page like a traditional book, can be removed from its jacket and unfolded flat to reference historical astronomical charts or contemporary NASA composite photos, or can be folded into an infinite variety of sculptural shapes." -- Author's website.
University of Denver Libraries' copy is no. 2/30 in limited ed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Stars
Poetry
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Fine Press and Artists' Books Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lebanese mountain cookery
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Laird, Mary Louise
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: French technique fine binding designed and created by artist Karen Hanmer. The binding is sewn on flattened cords laced into boards, covered in full goatskin. False raised bands. Inlays of goatskin and onlays using Paul Delrueâ€™s Lacunose technique of sanded leather scraps. Sunken suede doublure, leather flyleaves. Hand sewn.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The raven ; and, Berenice
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Edgar Allan Poe
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: " ... Ten leather and fifty linen copies were bound at the Florentine Bookbindery ... Hill Press is operated by Stephen Heaver, Jr. ... The [two full pages] wood engravings were executed by Sandy Connors of The Honeybee Press."--Colophon.

Box and binding designed and created by artist Karen Hanmer in 2009 for the University of Denver, University of Denver Libraries. "'Gebrochene rucken' variation of the Bradel binding, covered in full leather over Japanese tissue inspired by Paul Delrue's Lacunose technique. Goatskin onlay, hinges and endbands, graphite edges, blind stamping. (9.5 x 6 x 5 in.) Repeated stamping of key words from two Poe short stories reinforces their themes of obsession. Onlay references a bird wing, shroud or clawlike hand." -- From insert.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Poetry
Ravens
